thread.title: Detroit Lions' Zach Zenner: With pain subsiding, he might run soon
thread.title_full: Detroit Lions' Zach Zenner: With pain subsiding, he might run soon

author: freep.com
title: Detroit Lions' Zach Zenner: With pain subsiding, he might run soon
text:
MORE Zach Zenner reached for his backpack in very robotic fashion, bending slightly at the waist, grabbing the straps slowly and lifting it off of the floor.
Five days after he broke four ribs in five different places and suffered a partially collapsed lung , Zenner was back at the Detroit Lions' practice facility for a medical checkup today.
He spent five minutes talking to reporters while waiting for his Uber driver and said that the immense pain he felt during Sunday's 37-34 win over the Chicago Bears has subsided and that he could be back running soon.
"Really, it was hard to breathe, at first," Zenner said. "I just couldn't get a full breath, and my chest was kind of spasming and my abs, they were locked up just trying to keep my body stable. So not being able to get a full breath was uncomfortable, but then I was able to just kind of control it with shallow breaths. And then all the movement that I did, basically getting to the hospital, was very painful. Put the chest tube in to reinflate, to re-establish the pressure difference and help reinflate my lung. So that was probably the worst thing I've ever had to go through, painwise."
Zenner left Sunday's game after being sandwiched by two Bears defenders on a 7-yard run early in the second quarter.
The play that ended Zach Zenner's rookie year. Stumbled & took a shot from rookie safety Adrian Amos. https://t.co/eVry22uBSy @davebirkett
â€” The Answer (@MarloweAlter) October 19, 2015 He said he first thought he got the wind knocked out of him, but after a sideline examination, team doctors escorted him to the locker room. At halftime, he was taken to a hospital by ambulance.
Zenner spent two nights in the hospital, where he said he had a constant stream of visitors and got phone calls from Lions coach Jim Caldwell and general manager Martin Mayhew.
"(All things) considering, I feel really good," Zenner said. "Trying to control my body movements where it's like, 'Eh.' It's the little things. All of a sudden, you move a certain way, and it's like, 'Ooh, that one got to me a little bit.' But for the most part, sitting still, I feel good."
Zenner, who's second on the Lions with 60 rushing yards on 17 carries, said the timing of his injury has been even tougher to deal with than the pain.
The Lions are 1-5 with the NFL's last-ranked rushing offense, and Zenner appeared to be on his way to supplanting Joique Bell as the team's' between-the-tackles complement to Ameer Abdullah when he got hurt.
"That's the hardest pill to swallow, honestly," Zenner said. "Just finally worked so hard to get to that point, and then have it all end so suddenly. But at the same time, I'm going to be getting back, getting ready to rock next year."
For now, Abdullah, Bell and Theo Riddick will continue to split time in the Lions' backfield. But with no ribs displaced, Zenner said he's close to feeling normal again.
"I'll probably be up and running around next week," he said. "It's all whatever I can handle. There's nothing you can do."
